title: Richard Witting
text:
Richard Witting (born: Witkowski; 19 October 1856, <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a> – 22 December 1923, Berlin) was a <a href="Prussia">Prussia</a>n <a href="politician">politician</a> and <a href="financier">financier</a>. 
Witting studied <a href="law">law</a> at <a href="G%C3%B6ttingen">Göttingen</a>, where he became member of <a href="Burschenschaft%20Hannovera">Burschenschaft Hannovera</a> (fraternity), and later became mayor of <a href="Pozna%C5%84">Poznań</a> in 1891–1902. From 1902 to 1910 he was director of Nationalbank für Deutschland (National Bank for Germany). Witting was a brother of <a href="Maximilian%20Harden">Maximilian Harden</a> and father-in-law of <a href="Hans%20Paasche">Hans Paasche</a>. Witting is considered one of the major authors ("fathers") of the democratic <a href="Weimar%20Constitution">Weimar Constitution</a>, which he and <a href="Hugo%20Preu%C3%9F">Hugo Preuß</a> worked out in first drafts. He was also a convert to Lutheran Protestantism from Judaism, a common practice of this epoch.
